summary: On May 2, 2019, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New Mexico entered a final judgment against the defendants in an as-implemented energy challenge brought by the New Mexico Public Regulation Commission (PURC).  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Albuquerque, New Mexico, alleges that, in 2016, the Commission issued an order requiring electric utilities to purchase power from qualified, non-residential power producers (QFs) by the date of interconnection at the time the QFs were scheduled to be built.  The complaint further alleges that the Commission's order required QFs to be ready to interconnect and deliver energy at a reasonable time, and that QFs did not comply with PURC's requirements.  According to the complaint, QFs are not subject to the same federal and state requirements as QFs, and QFs do not qualify for the same exemption.  In addition, the complaint alleges that in 2016 and 2017, the N.M. Department of Public Regulation (DPRC) issued a final order requiring QF-qualified facilities to purchase electricity from QFs at a time when QFs had become increasingly dependent on foreign oil.  As alleged in the SEC's Complaint, this order violated PURPA and FERC's requirements for QFs.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the Commission’s complaint, the defendants consented to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining them from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, ordering them to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and ordering the defendants to pay civil penalties in the amount of $1,000,000.  Additionally, the court granted the defendants' requests for a temporary restraining order, an asset freeze, and an accounting of QFs' avoided costs.  On May 4, 2020, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action against Great Divide Wind Farm 2 LLC, Windway Techs., Inc. v. Midland Power Co. (M.D. Tex.), alleging that Great Divide violated the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act") and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act"), and Rules 10b-5, 13a-1, 13b2-2, and 13b-11 thereunder, and seeks a permanent injunction against future violations of the charged federal laws, as well as an order appointing a receiver to oversee QFs in violation of Section 15(a)(1) and Rule 15a-3 thereunder of the Exchange Act.   The Commission's complaint charges Great Divide with violating Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4) of
